question.text: The ammonia <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfenced></math> released on quantitative reaction of <math><mn>0.6 </mn><mi mathvariant="normal"></mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> urea <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfenced></math> with sodium hydroxide <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mfenced></math> can be neutralized by

options.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>200</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.4</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>200</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.2</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mn>00</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.2</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>100</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.1</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></math>

solution.text:
NH2CONH2 + 2NaOH →2NH3 +Na2CO3

By, stoichiometry, 1 mol of urea gives 2 mol NH3

Moles of urea ==0.6 gm60 gm/mol=0.01 mol

So, 0.01 mole urea produce 0.02 mole NH3

To neutralize ammonia HCl is required

NH3 +HCl→ NH4Cl

By equation, it is clear that 1 mol of ammonia is neutralized by 1mol of HCl.

So, 0.02 mol of ammonia neutralized by 0.02 mol of HCl

∴Mole of HCl=0.02 mole

Equivalent of HCl=normality×volume=0.2 N×100 mL=0.02 equivalent

As n-factor of HCl is 1, so number of equivalents=number of moles=0.02 moles

Hence, option 3 is correct.
